reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s linear/unbounded-resource discussion, especially the “Milky Way is 1/20Bth of value” style arithmetic and the associated ‘fanaticism’ comparison that treats additional cosmic resources as roughly fungible. That component supports (but is not the sole support for) the broader ‘no easy eutopia / most plausible views are fussy’ conclusion, so undermining it would weaken the case but not collapse it (other pillars: multiplicative fragility, moral-catasrophe examples, bounded-view fussiness). The objection is moderately strong: real expansion plausibly has sharply rising marginal costs/risks (time lags, coordination, security, thermodynamics), so counting raw galaxies as proportional value is too quick unless “resources” are already defined net of these costs. However, the position can be patched by redefining ‘resources under control’ to mean cost-adjusted usable resources, and linear separability doesn’t itself entail negligible capture costs; so the critique doesn’t fully refute the linear-view argument. Most claims are plausible/correct, though some (e.g., predicting it will justify reckless conflict) are speculative and somewhat rhetorical. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little non-contributing material.
title: Cosmic resource expansion assumptions overlook practical limits
